fields.headline: A world of one's own
fields.bodyText: Cecily Brown: New Paintings Gagosian Gallery, Britannia Street, London WC1, Tues-Sat until 27 May There's a certain degree of turmoil and disturbance in Cecily Brown's paintings. The paint on her giant canvases (12 in this exhibition) roils with tension as the viewer is gradually absorbed. These are not immediate works; they take some unravelling as familiar objects swim into view. In Baise-en-ville a woman, naked from the waist up, looks languidly into a hand mirror. Her lovers are wraiths behind her and some scant coals burn in the grate. She is oblivious of the carnage in the street below, where lie a twisted red double-decker bus and crumpled car - echoes of the Tavistock Square July bomb. In Maid's Day Off a more benign chaos surrounds a pensive figure, indifferent to the welter of clothes and bedding; the title explains all. Brown's figures exude an unembarrassed nonchalance: a couple having sex in an apocalyptic sandy landscape in Autumn Rhythm; a corpulent pair doing it standing up in a book-strewn study in New Louboutin Pumps Brown's strongest works are her most ambiguous - was that Manhattan and the 59th Street Bridge in Adoration of the Lamb? I wondered. It doesn't really matter because it's such a great picture. This is a terrific show.
